comment: Bogoljubov shows himeself too optimistic. He declines the queen exchange because he thinks he can win. (Le Lionnais) Please, don't tell us that Efim Dmitrjevic, at this point of the game, still thought he could win. We can believe that it was not clear to him what the outcome of the game would be, but we swear that he declined the queen exchange for a insane and masochist curiosity to know if and how that small italian (maybe he considered him almost like an ant compared to him?) could bring his attack to an end. He did not know yet, that even an ant, when he is mad, can be dangerous.
reasoning: The comment explains the mistake made by the player as he played the move based on overconfidence and curiosity rather than strategic thinking, resulting in a potentially dangerous position.

comment: !! - A sacrifice with a threefold effect: it nullifies the defense of the Rook d2 (37.Kh2 Qg2 mate), opens the path to his own Rook and deprives the enemy King of an escape square. (Tartakower). If there was absolute silence in the hall, after this move one could have heard the heartbeat and the bowels of Bogoljubov (but maybe Monticelli too). The ukrainian GM, after the surprise of the first moment, surely saw the solution found by his opponent, nevertheless he did take the opportunity to stop the clock. We think that in front of the sadistic happiness of the italian man in giving the last razor shots, he want to face his masochist happiness in recieve them.
reasoning: The comment accurately explains the mistake made by the player by highlighting the strategic consequences of the move and the missed opportunity to exploit the opponent's weaknesses.
